entry.title: Set Matrix Zeroes
entry.content:
Question

I firstly figure out O(m + n) solution, that is to create two HashSets, one containing the rows where exist 0 element, the other columns. Then traverse through those two sets, and set the corresponding rows and columns to 0. The code follows below:

 1    public void setZeroes(int[][] matrix) {
 2        
 3        Set<Integer> zeroRow = new HashSet<>();
 4        Set<Integer> zeroColumn = new HashSet<>();
 5
 6        for (int i = 0; i < matrix.length; i++) {
 7            for (int j = 0; j < matrix[0].length; j++) {
 8                if (matrix[i][j] == 0) {
 9                    zeroRow.add(i);
10                    zeroColumn.add(j);
11                }
12            }
13        }
14        
15        for (Integer row : zeroRow) {
16            setRowZero(matrix, row);
17        }
18        
19        for (Integer column : zeroColumn) {
20            setColumnZero(matrix, column);
21        }
22    }
23
24    /* Helper Functions */
25
26    private void setRowZero(int[][] matrix, int row) {
27        for (int i = 0; i < matrix[0].length; i++) {
28            matrix[row][i] = 0;
29        }
30    }
31    
32    private void setColumnZero(int[][] matrix, int column) {
33        for (int i = 0; i < matrix.length; i++) {
34            matrix[i][column] = 0;
35        }
36    }

However, as mentioned in the question, this is not the best solution. It’s able to devise a constant space solution. We can take the first row and first column in the matrix to flag. For example, if matrix[i][j] is 0, then we set the corresponding matrix[i][0] and matrix[0][j] as 0. Note we need to take care of these things: 1. As the first row and first column would be overwritten, we need firstly determine if there is 0 on the them before we go to flag. 2. After finishing the flag job, we are going to set zeroes, here we not only need set the rows and columns whose corresponding flag rows and columns have zeroes, but also keep the flag row and column not overwritten by 0, thus we need firstly set zeroes except for first row and column, then according to 1, at last we deal with the first row and column. The code follows below:

 1    public void setZeroes2(int[][] matrix) {
 2        boolean firstRowZero = false;
 3        boolean firstColumnZero = false;
 4
 5        /* determine if there is zero in first row and first column */
 6        if (matrix[0][0] == 0) {
 7            firstRowZero = true;
 8            firstColumnZero = true;
 9        } else {
10            for (int i = 1; i < matrix.length; i++) {
11                if (matrix[i][0] == 0) {
12                    firstColumnZero = true;
13                }
14            }
15
16            for (int i = 1; i < matrix[0].length; i++) {
17                if (matrix[0][i] == 0) {
18                    firstRowZero = true;
19                }
20            }
21        }
22        
23        /* make first row and first column as the counting row and column */
24        for (int i = 1; i < matrix.length; i++) {
25            for (int j = 1; j < matrix[0].length; j++) {
26                if (matrix[i][j] == 0) {
27                    matrix[0][j] = 0;
28                    matrix[i][0] = 0;
29                }
30            }
31        }
32
33        /* set zeroes except for first row and column */
34        for (int i = 1; i < matrix.length; i++) {
35            if (matrix[i][0] == 0) {
36                setRowZero(matrix, i);
37            }
38        }
39
40        for (int i = 1; i < matrix[0].length; i++) {
41            if (matrix[0][i] == 0) {
42                setColumnZero(matrix, i);
43            }
44        }
45
46        /* set zeroes for first row and column */
47        if (firstColumnZero) {
48            setColumnZero(matrix, 0);
49        }
50
51        if (firstRowZero) {
52            setRowZero(matrix, 0);
53        }
54
55    }

entry.title: Gray Code
entry.content:
Question

After seeing this question, my first thought is to try flipping each bit and compare it to the elements in the returnarr to see if the flipped elements exists there. If not, I’ll continue flipping the next bit. The code follows below:

 1    public List<Integer> grayCode(int n) {
 2        List<Integer> codeList = new ArrayList<>();
 3        int base = 0;
 4
 5        /* begin with 0 */
 6        codeList.add(base);
 7
 8        while (codeList.size() < Math.pow(2, n)) {
 9            for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
10                int newBase;
11
12                if ((base >> i) % 2 == 0) {
13                    newBase = base + (1 << i);
14                } else {
15                    newBase = base - (1 << i);
16                }
17
18                if (!codeList.contains(newBase)) {
19                    codeList.add(newBase);
20                    base = newBase;
21                    break;
22                }
23            }
24        }
25
26        return codeList;
27    }

However, this method will take at least O(n*2^n) time complexity. Thanks to this website, giving a O(2^n) time complexity algorithm, efficient and genius as well. The method is basically from this: To calculate gray code sequence of 1 bit, only need to flip the last bit from 0 to 1.

0
1

Move to 2 bits, as shown above, first generate a gray code sequence of 1 bit, then go backwards and flip the second bit from 0 to 1.

00
01 ↑
---
11 ↓
10

Move to 3 bits, first generate a gray code sequence of 2 bits, then go backwards and flip the third bit from 0 to 1.

000
001
011
010 ↑
-----
110 ↓
111
101
100

we can generate n bits gray code by generating n - 1 bits gray code firstly, and flip the highest bit from 0 to 1. Thus we can go all way down to 1 bit and start from there. The code follows below:

 1    public List<Integer> grayCode2(int n) {
 2        List<Integer> codeList = new ArrayList<>();
 3
 4        /* begin with 0 */
 5        codeList.add(0);
 6
 7        for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
 8            for (int j = codeList.size() - 1; j >= 0; j--) {
 9                codeList.add(codeList.get(j) | 1 << i);
10            }
11        }
12
13        return codeList;
14    }

entry.title: Climbing Stairs
entry.content:
Question

We can solve this question by taking advantage of Fibonacci number. To get the distinct ways to climb n steps, we can separate it into two parts, first taking one step, then the ways is the same with climeStair(n - 1); Second taking two steps, then the the ways is the same with climeStair(n - 2). In total, climeStair(n) = climeStair(n - 1) + climeStair(n - 2), which is actually to find the _n_th Fibonacci number. The code follows here:

 1    public int climbStairs(int n) {
 2        if (n <= 2) {
 3            return n;
 4        }
 5        int[] steps = new int[n + 1];
 6        steps[1] = 1;
 7        steps[2] = 2;
 8        for(int i = 3; i <= n; i++) {
 9            steps[i] = steps[i - 1] + steps[i - 2];
10        }
11        return steps[n];
12    }

entry.title: Plus One
entry.content:
Question

For this question, I take advantage of a helper function plusOneHelper, which will add one to the end element of array digit, if the result is smaller than 10, we can return. If not, we set the digit on that index 0 and recursively call this helper function on the array from start to end-1. After running this helper function, we determine if the first element of the array is 0, if not we return the original array. Otherwise, we create a new array newDigit, starting with 1, and copy the rest from digits. Here is the code:

 1    public int[] plusOne(int[] digits) {
 2
 3        plusOneHelper(digits, 0, digits.length - 1);
 4
 5        if (digits[0] == 0) {
 6            int[] newDigit = new int[digits.length + 1];
 7            newDigit[0] = 1;
 8            for (int i = 0; i < digits.length; i++) {
 9                newDigit[i + 1] = digits[i];
10            }
11            return newDigit;
12        }
13
14        return digits;
15    }
16
17    /* Helper Functions */
18
19    private void plusOneHelper(int[] digits, int start, int end) {
20        if (end < start) {
21            return;
22        }
23        int base = digits[end];
24        base += 1;
25        if (base < 10) {
26            digits[end] = base;
27        } else {
28            digits[end] = 0;
29            plusOneHelper(digits, start, end - 1);
30        }
31    }

entry.title: Rotate Image
entry.content:
Question

We regard the matrix as made by different levels of circles (square though). For every circle, we do a rotation for every element in the circle. The code follows here:

 1    public void rotate(int[][] matrix) {
 2        int n = matrix.length;
 3
 4        for (int i = 0; i < n / 2; i++) {
 5            for (int j = i; j < n - i - 1; j++) {
 6                rotateElement(matrix, i, j);
 7            }
 8        }
 9
10    }
11
12    /* Helper Functions */
13
14    private void rotateElement(int[][] matrix, int i, int j) {
15        int n = matrix.length;
16        int temp = matrix[i][j];
17        matrix[i][j] = matrix[n - 1 - j][i];
18        matrix[n - 1 - j][i] = matrix[n - 1 - i][n - 1 - j];
19        matrix[n - 1 - i][n - 1 - j] = matrix[j][n - 1 - i];
20        matrix[j][n - 1 - i] = temp;
21    }

entry.title: Trapping Rain Water
entry.content:
Question

For every slot, we find both the highest elevation of its left slots and right slots, the smaller of which will be the local maximum height. Next we need to compare this height, say maxh with the height of the slot, say h, if h is larger, meaning it’s not able to trap water as it itself is the highest. If not, we can trap mh - h amount of water. Here follows the code:

 1    public int trap(int[] A) {
 2        if (A.length == 0) {
 3            return 0;
 4        }
 5        
 6        /* Initialize leftMax and rightMax */
 7        int leftMax = A[0];
 8        int rightMax = 0;
 9        for (int i = 1; i < A.length; i++) {
10            if (A[i] > rightMax) {
11                rightMax = A[i];
12            }
13        }
14        
15        /* Get capacity of every slot */
16        int capacity = 0;
17        for (int i = 1; i < A.length - 1; i++) {
18            int left = 0;
19            int right = 0;
20
21            if (leftMax > A[i]) {
22                left = leftMax;
23            } else {
24                leftMax = A[i];
25            }
26
27            if (rightMax > A[i]) {
28                right = rightMax;
29            } else {
30                int newRightMax = 0;
31                for (int j = i + 1; j < A.length; j++) {
32                    if (A[j] > newRightMax) {
33                        newRightMax = A[j];
34                    }
35                }
36                rightMax = newRightMax;
37            }
38
39            int localMax = left > right ? right : left;
40            capacity += localMax > A[i] ? localMax - A[i] : 0;
41        }
42
43        return capacity;
44    }

entry.title: Valid Sudoku
entry.content:
Question

This is a simple question, as the rules of a valid sudoku is already given. We just need to follow the rules to implement the function.

Here I convert int i to char by using (char)(‘0’ + i). The whole code snippet follows here:

 1    public boolean isValidSudoku(char[][] board) {
 2        Set<Character> set1 = new HashSet<>();
 3        Set<Character> set2 = new HashSet<>();
 4        for (int i = 0; i < 9; i++) {
 5            setUp(set1);
 6            setUp(set2);
 7            for (int j = 0; j < 9; j++) {
 8                char num;
 9                // Each row must have the numbers 1-9 occuring just once.
10                if ((num = board[i][j]) != '.') {
11                    if (set1.contains(num)) {
12                        set1.remove(num);
13                    } else {
14                        return false;
15                    }
16                }
17                // Each column must have the numbers 1-9 occuring just once.
18                if ((num = board[j][i]) != '.') {
19                    if (set2.contains(num)) {
20                        set2.remove(num);
21                    } else {
22                        return false;
23                    }
24                }
25            }
26        }
27
28        // the numbers 1-9 must occur just once in each of the 9 sub-boxes of
29        // the grid.
30        for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
31            for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) {
32                int m = i * 3;
33                int n = j * 3;
34                setUp(set1);
35                for (int k = m; k < m + 3; k++) {
36                    for (int l = n; l < n + 3; l++) {
37                        char num;
38                        if ((num = board[k][l]) == '.')
39                            continue;
40                        if (set1.contains(num)) {
41                            set1.remove(num);
42                        } else {
43                            return false;
44                        }
45                    }
46                }
47            }
48        }
49        return true;
50    }
51
52    /* Helper Functions */
53    public void setUp(Set<Character> set) {
54        for (int i = 1; i <= 9; i++) {
55            set.add((char) ('0' + i));
56        }
57    }

entry.title: Permutation Sequence
entry.content:
Question

We have already solved Next Permutation question, with the help of this, we just need a loop to find the k th string. Here are the code:

 1public String getPermutation(int n, int k) {
 2    int[] num = new int[n];
 3    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
 4        num[i] = i + 1;
 5    }
 6    
 7    for(int i = 1; i < k; i++ ) {
 8        nextPermutation(num);
 9    }
10        
11    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
12    for(int i : num) {
13        sb.append(i);
14    }
15    return sb.toString();
16}

entry.title: Next Permutation
entry.content:
Question

For this question, in order to get the next larger permutation, we need start from the last element, compare it with the previous element to see if it’s larger(if not, swapping them would make the number smaller). We start from index arr.length -2 to 0 to see which element could be swapped, say we are now at index i, then we use j to traverse from index arr.length -1 to i - 1 to see if arr[i] is smaller than arr[j], if so we can safely swap them(As if we come to index i, the elements from index i + 1 to arr.length -1 must be in decreasing order, otherwise, the swap would happen before i). After we swap, there need two things to be done, first we sort the array after index i(here I use insertion sort), then we return directly. If the previous requirement not met, we simply sort and return.

 1public void nextPermutation(int[] num) {
 2    int lastIndex = num.length - 1;
 3    for (int i = lastIndex - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
 4        for (int j = lastIndex; j > i; j--) {
 5            if (num[i] < num[j]) {
 6                swap(num, i, j);
 7
 8                for (int m = i + 2; m <= num.length - 1; m++) {
 9                    for (int n = m; n > i + 1 && num[n] < num[n - 1]; n--) {
10                        swap(num, n, n - 1);
11                    }
12                }
13                return;
14            }
15        }
16    }
17
18    Arrays.sort(num);
19}
20
21/* Helper Functions */
22public void swap(int[] num, int i, int j) {
23    int temp = num[i];
24    num[i] = num[j];
25    num[j] = temp;
26}

entry.title: Remove Elements
entry.content:
Question

This question is an easier version of Remove duplicates in array. Below follows the code:

 1    public int removeElement(int[] A, int elem) {
 2        int offset = 0;
 3    
 4        for (int i = 0; i < A.length; i++) {
 5            if (A[i] == elem) {
 6                offset++;
 7            } else {
 8                A[i - offset] = A[i];
 9            }
10        }
11    
12        return A.length - offset;
13    }

entry.title: Relearn Java Day 4 OOP
entry.content:
• Encapsulation
    • hide details, including private the member variable.(set(), get())
    • class, framework are also encapsulation
  • Anonymous object
    • new Car();
    • when member functions only called once, we can use anonymous object
    • can be regarded as function arguments.
  • Member variable:
    • when object created, the corresponding member variables are initialized with default value (as the object is created in heap)

    • the difference between member variable and local variable:

      • member variable is defined in the block of class, can be visited through the class. local variable is defined in the block of function.
      • member variable is created in heap, while local variable in stack.
      • member variable exists with class, local variable exists with it’s corresponding blcok(functions).
      • member variable has default value, local variable doesn’t
  • Constructor
    • when newed, constructor functions must be called
    • no return value, name is the same with the class.
    • if not defined, there would be a default constructor function. If defined, the default one not used.
    • could be overloaded

entry.title: Num Sum
entry.content:
Questions:

Two Sum

Three Sum

Two Sum :
If we use brute force, the time complexity would be O(n^2), we can figure out a better way. Try to think like this, first we get an element(say, at index i) of the array, next we can determine if target-element is in the array(with the help of other data structures like HashSet). As there would be only one solution, we can safely return if we can find target-element in the array from index i+1 to arr.length-1.

 1    public int[] twoSum(int[] numbers, int target) {
 2        int len = numbers.length;
 3        Set<Integer> set = new HashSet<>();
 4        
 5        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
 6            int val = numbers[i];
 7            set.add(val);
 8        }
 9        
10        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
11            int goal = target - numbers[i];
12
13            if (set.contains(goal)) {
14                for (int j = i + 1; j < len; j++) {
15                    if(numbers[j] == goal) {
16                        return new int[]{i + 1, j + 1};
17                    }
18                }
19            }
20        }
21        return null;
22    }

Three Sum With the help of three sum’s wiki page, we can get the following code. Note in order to eliminate duplicate arrays, we need take advantage of HashSet, which can automatically help determine if the elements of two arrayList are the same.

 1public class Solution {
 2    List<List<Integer>> sumList;
 3    Set<List<Integer>> set;
 4    List<Integer> list;
 5
 6    public List<List<Integer>> threeSum(int[] num) {
 7        Arrays.sort(num);
 8        sumList = new ArrayList<>();
 9        set = new HashSet<>();
10        for (int i = 0; i < num.length - 3; i++) {
11            int first = num[i];
12
13            int j = i + 1;
14            int k = num.length - 1;
15
16            while (j < k) {
17                int second = num[j];
18                int third = num[k];
19                int result = first + second + third;
20                if (result == 0) {
21                    list = new ArrayList<>();
22                    list.add(first);
23                    list.add(second);
24                    list.add(third);
25                    set.add(list);
26                    j++;
27                    k--;
28                } else {
29                    if (result < 0) {
30                        j++;
31                    } else {
32                        k--;
33                    }
34                }
35            }
36        }
37        sumList.addAll(set);
38        return sumList;
39    }
40}

entry.title: Relearn Java Day 3 Arrays
entry.content:
Arrays：

  • initialization:
    • int[] arr = new int[5]; //the default value would be 0(default value of int)
    • int[] arr = new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    • int[] arr = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};

  • sort:

    • Arrays.sort([]);

  • BinarySearch:

    • Arrays.binarySearch(arr,key);//如果存在返回的具体的角标位置，不存在返回的是 -插入点-1 
 1public static int halfSearch_2(int[] arr,int key)
 2    {
 3        int max,min,mid;
 4        min = 0;
 5        max = arr.length-1;
 6
 7        while(min<=max)
 8        {
 9            mid = (max+min)>>1;
10
11            if(key>arr[mid])
12                min = mid + 1;
13            else if(key<arr[mid])
14                max = mid - 1;
15            else
16                return mid;
17        }
18        return -1;
19    }

entry.title: Relearn Java Day 2
entry.content:
1.Break:

  • jump out of only : switch, loop
  • break designated loop : break + 标号

2.Overload:
> 1. 同一个类，
2. 同名。
3. 参数个数不同。or 参数类型不同。
4. 函数重载和返回值类型无关。
5. java是严谨性语言，如果函数出现的调用的不确定性，会编译失败。

3.Division of JVM:
> 1. 寄存器。
2. 本地方法区。
和所在系统有关 3. 方法区。
4. 栈内存（Stack）。
存储的都是局部变量。
而且变量所属的作用域一旦结束，该变量就自动释放。 特点：生命周期短，处理速度快 5. 堆内存(Heap)。
存储是数组和对象(其实数组就是对象) 凡是new建立在堆中。
特点：
1. 每一个实体都有首地址值。
2. 堆内存中的每一个变量都有默认初始化值，根据类型的不同而不同。整数是0，小数0.0或者0.0f，boolean false char ‘\u0000’
3. 垃圾回收机制。

entry.title: Search in Rotated Sorted Array
entry.content:
Q：Suppose a sorted array is rotated at some pivot unknown to you beforehand.You are given a target value to search. If found in the array return its index, otherwise return -1.You may assume no duplicate exists in the array.

Q2:Follow up for “Search in Rotated Sorted Array”: What if duplicates are allowed?
Would this affect the run-time complexity? How and why?
Write a function to determine if a given target is in the array.

For sorted array not rotated, we use binary search, the runtime of which would be O(logn). The basic steps would be : > 1. Set left be the left most point of the array, similar to right 2. Set mid to be the mid point of the array : (left + right) / 2 3. If mid element is equal to target, we return the index 4. Otherwise, we compare the mid element with target, and repeat these steps on the subtracted array (either left to mid-1 or mid+1 to right)。 5. If we can’t find one before left <= right, we will return -1.

Now the array is rotated, while when doing binary search, after mid divides the array into two parts, there must be one part that is in sequence. Thus we can adjust the previous solution a little bit, that is, after step 3, we figure out which part is in sequence, then we judge whether the target would reside in the part. If so, actually it becomes same with normal binary search, if not, it must reside in the other part(based on the fact that the target is in the array), then we can repeat the procedure again on the subtracted array.

If duplicates are allowed, we have no idea if the part is in sequence by comparing left and mid(or mid and right) as they may be the same. Thus we need figure if target must reside in one of the two parts(to see if left<target<mid or mid < target < right), if so, we do the same previously. Otherwise, if we could not make sure either of them, we need narrow the range of left to right and repeat the procedure again. By doing so, the runtime would be O(n) in worst. Here is the detail:

entry.title: Relearn Java Day 1
entry.content:
The foundation is so important for a skyscraper, thus I want to rebuild, or, renovate of my java foundation in the next few weeks. I will post valuable points here in this relearn java series. Here is Day 1:

  1. Basic Conceptions:
    • Java Virtual Machine(JVM):
      • help Java become cross-platform language(note jvm isn’t cross-platform)
      • between language and operating system
    • Java Runtime Environment(JRE)
      • JVM + 核心类库
    • Java Development Kit(JDK)
      • JRE + javac.exe + jar.exe + …
  2. Comment
    • one line : //
    • multiple line: /* */
    • 文档注释： /** */
  3. Bit computing
    • & and. could used to get several bits of bytes.
      • not the difference between & and && is && is more efficient when the left of && is false(it will stop calculating the right one).
    • ^ xor. note you can get the original number by xor two times
      • change the value of variable a, b in place :
        a = a ^ b; b = a ^ b; a = a ^ b;
    • « 左移 （该数乘以2的几次方）
    • » 右移 （该数除以2的几次方）对于高位出现的空位， 补与原来相同的数
    • »> 无论原来高位是什么 都用0来补
  4. switch :
    • the types that could be compared ： byte, short, int, char

entry.title: Remove Duplicates in Array
entry.content:
Q1: Given a sorted array, remove the duplicates in place such that each element appear only once and return the new length. Do not allocate extra space for another array, you must do this in place with constant memory.

Q2:Follow up for “Remove Duplicates”: What if duplicates are allowed at most twice?

If we adjust the position of every element whenever there happens a duplicate, the running time would be large. In order to be more efficient, we can do in this way: if the element is the same with the previous one, we increase a “offset”(recording the offset) variable by one. When traversing through every element, say index of i, we adjust the position from i to i - offset.

For question 2, the solution is similar except for we need know when to increase the offset. We use a variable “count” to count, the following code show the details:

entry.title: BFS and DFS
entry.content:
Recently I’ve been doing LeetCode Problems and found it’s tons of fun. Meanwhile I felt my lacking of solid way solving basic questions, e.g. the topic of the post today : BFS and DFS.I searched through the Internet and found this post really helps me a lot.

Basically it’s important to know which data structure we use to implement the algorithm, for DFS we use Stack and for BFS we use Queue.

The steps for DFS:
>Step 1: Push the root node in the Stack.
Step 2: Loop until stack is empty.
Step 3: Peek the node of the stack.
Step 4: If the node has unvisited child nodes, get the unvisited child node, mark it as traversed and push it on stack.
Step 5: If the node does not have any unvisited child nodes, pop the node from the stack.

The steps for DFS:
>Step 1: Push the root node in the Queue.
Step 2: Loop until the queue is empty.
Step 3: Remove the node from the Queue.
Step 4: If the removed node has unvisited child nodes, mark them as visited and insert the unvisited children in the queue.
